course.title: General Psychology
course.subtitle: Scientific Study of Human Behavior & Mental Processes
course.description: Scientific study of behavior and mental processes, including research methods, biopsychology, learning, cognition, development, personality, social psychology, and psychological disorders.

psychologicalThinkingSkills.name: Scientific Reasoning & Research Literacy
psychologicalThinkingSkills.description: Ability to understand research design, distinguish evidence quality, evaluate claims using scientific method
progression: Module 1: Identify types of research (experimental, correlational, descriptive)
Module 2: Distinguish credible from questionable sources in biopsychology
Module 3: Analyze research validity (confounds, controls, causation)
Module 5: Evaluate competing theories using evidence
Module 7: Critique diagnostic criteria and research on disorders
Module 8: Synthesize research findings across course

psychologicalThinkingSkills.name: Application of Psychological Principles
psychologicalThinkingSkills.description: Transfer concepts from abstract theory to real-world contexts (personal, social, organizational)
progression: Module 1: Identify psychological approaches in everyday scenarios
Module 2: Apply brain function knowledge to injury cases or behaviors
Module 3: Apply learning principles to change your own behavior
Module 4: Synthesize multiple principles (Midterm Project)
Module 5: Apply motivation theories to workplace situations
Module 6: Apply personality theories to understand self/others
Module 7: Apply coping strategies to manage personal stress
Module 8: Integrate principles to analyze complex case

psychologicalThinkingSkills.name: Biopsychosocial Integration
psychologicalThinkingSkills.description: Analyze psychological phenomena using biological, psychological, and social/cultural lenses simultaneously
progression: Module 2: Introduce the biopsychosocial model (brain-behavior connections)
Module 3: Apply to memory (biology, cognition, social context)
Module 5: Apply to emotion and motivation (three levels)
Module 6: Analyze personality development across three levels
Module 7: Understand psychological disorders through biopsychosocial lens
Module 8: Full integration in final assessments

psychologicalThinkingSkills.name: Ethical Analysis & Professional Standards
psychologicalThinkingSkills.description: Identify ethical issues, apply APA principles, consider cultural and power dynamics
progression: Module 1: Learn APA ethical principles (informed consent, confidentiality, harm)
Module 2: Analyze historical ethical violations (eugenics, lobotomy)
Module 3: Evaluate ethical concerns in memory research (false memories, eyewitness)
Module 6: Apply ethics to social influence research (Milgram, Stanford Prison)
Module 7: Consider ethics in diagnosis and treatment (labeling, stigma)
Module 8: Synthesize ethical reasoning across contexts

psychologicalThinkingSkills.name: Data Literacy & Visual Analysis
psychologicalThinkingSkills.description: Interpret graphs, charts, statistics, and quantitative findings in psychological research
progression: Module 1: Read basic research results tables
Module 2: Interpret brain scan images and neurological data
Module 3: Analyze learning curves and memory retention graphs
Module 5: Interpret emotional intelligence and IQ distribution data
Module 6: Analyze personality assessment results and normal distributions
Module 7: Interpret prevalence rates, comorbidity, and treatment effectiveness

psychologicalThinkingSkills.name: Critical Evaluation of Psychological Claims
psychologicalThinkingSkills.description: Assess popular psychology claims, identify pseudoscience, distinguish science from belief
progression: Module 1: Learn hallmarks of pseudoscience vs science
Module 2: Debunk neuromyths (left-brain/right-brain, 10% brain use)
Module 3: Evaluate learning styles myth using evidence
Module 5: Critique media portrayals of intelligence
Module 6: Analyze popular personality assessments (Myers-Briggs vs Big Five)
Module 7: Evaluate mental health treatments (evidence-based vs pseudoscience)
Module 8: Apply critical lens to contemporary psychology claims

clos.text: Explain major psychological concepts, theoretical perspectives, and historical trends using discipline-specific terminology
Evaluate research methods and designs to determine appropriate use and validity in psychological investigations
Analyze psychological phenomena and problems using scientific reasoning and evidence-based approaches
Apply psychological principles to solve personal, social, and organizational problems
Synthesize biological, psychological, and social factors to explain human behavior and mental processes

modules.title: Introduction to Psychology & Research Methods
inquiryQuestions: How did psychology emerge as a scientific discipline separate from philosophy?
What makes psychological research 'scientific' compared to common sense or folk wisdom?
Why do we need different research methods (experimental, correlational, descriptive)?

mlos.text: Describe the historical development of major psychological approaches (psychoanalytic, behavioral, cognitive, humanistic, biological, sociocultural)
Distinguish between types of psychological research and their appropriate uses
Analyze the ethical principles governing psychological research
Evaluate the validity and reliability of psychological claims using scientific reasoning

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 key terms from Module 1 to their definitions. Covers history of psychology, research methods, and ethical principles.

activities.title: LA2: Research Method Scenarios
activities.studentInstructions: Given 10 research questions, identify the most appropriate research method (experimental, correlational, or descriptive) and explain why. Analyze what conclusions each method can support.

activities.title: LA3: Analyzing Research Ethics
activities.studentInstructions: Review 3 controversial historical studies (Tuskegee Syphilis Study, Milgram Obedience, Stanford Prison Experiment). Evaluate what went wrong, what protections exist now, and how the APA Ethics Code addresses these issues.

activities.title: LA4: Student Choice Activity
activities.studentInstructions: Choose ONE: (A) Create timeline of psychology's development with key figures/events, OR (B) Analyze a current psychology study from news and identify research method, variables, and validity threats.

modules.title: Biopsychology, Sensation & Perception
inquiryQuestions: How does your brain create your experience of reality?
Why do two people looking at the same thing sometimes 'see' different things?
How can understanding brain function help us treat psychological disorders?

mlos.text: Explain the structure and function of neurons and neurotransmitters
Identify major brain structures and their roles in behavior and cognition
Apply principles of sensation and perception to explain perceptual illusions
Analyze case studies of brain injury using biopsychosocial model
Interpret neurological data and brain scan results

activities.title: LA1: Brain & Neuron Structures
activities.studentInstructions: Label major brain structures and neuron parts. Match brain regions to their primary functions. Test your understanding of neuroanatomy and neurotransmitters.

activities.title: LA2: Case Study Analysis
activities.studentInstructions: Analyze 3 famous case studies (Phineas Gage, H.M., Jill Bolte Taylor). Explain symptoms based on brain damage location and apply the biopsychosocial model.

activities.title: LA3: Perception & Illusions Lab
activities.studentInstructions: Explore 10 optical illusions. Explain the psychological principles behind each (Gestalt principles, depth perception, color perception, attention).

activities.title: LA4: Data Literacy - Brain Imaging
activities.studentInstructions: Interpret PET scans and fMRI data comparing brain activity during different tasks. Answer interpretation questions about localization of function.

modules.title: Learning & Memory
inquiryQuestions: How can understanding conditioning principles help you change your own behavior?
Why are eyewitness memories so confident yet so unreliable?
What memory techniques actually work according to research?

mlos.text: Distinguish between classical conditioning, operant conditioning, and observational learning
Apply learning principles to explain real-world behaviors and design behavior change plans
Explain the stages of memory (encoding, storage, retrieval) and common memory errors
Analyze the accuracy and limitations of eyewitness testimony using memory research
Evaluate study strategies based on cognitive psychology findings

activities.title: LA1: Learning Scenarios
activities.studentInstructions: Identify type of learning (classical, operant, observational) in 15 real-world scenarios. Identify key elements (UCS, CS, reinforcer, punishment, model).

activities.title: LA2: Behavior Change Project
activities.studentInstructions: Design a plan to change your own behavior using operant conditioning principles. Identify target behavior, choose reinforcement/punishment strategy, create schedule, track for 1 week, reflect on effectiveness.

activities.title: LA3: Memory Systems Activity
activities.studentInstructions: Experience different memory tasks (serial position effect, levels of processing, mnemonic techniques). Analyze your own performance using course concepts.

activities.title: LA4: Data Literacy - Memory Research
activities.studentInstructions: Analyze graphs showing forgetting curve, spacing effect, massed vs distributed practice. Answer interpretation questions about effective learning strategies.

modules.title: Midterm Review & Synthesis Project
inquiryQuestions: How do psychological concepts connect across topics (research, brain, learning)?
What patterns emerge when you synthesize learning from multiple areas?
How can creative projects demonstrate psychological understanding?

mlos.text: Synthesize concepts from research methods, biopsychology, learning, and memory
Create an original product that accurately represents psychological principles
Reflect on your own learning and identify areas for continued growth

activities.title: LA1: Cumulative Review Quiz
activities.studentInstructions: Mixed questions from Modules 1-3. Helps identify gaps and prepare for midterm project.

activities.title: LA2: Concept Mapping
activities.studentInstructions: Create visual map showing connections between concepts across first 3 modules. Show how research methods, brain function, and learning principles interconnect.

modules.title: Cognition, Emotion & Motivation
inquiryQuestions: How does language shape the way we think?
What role does emotional intelligence play in success?
Can motivation be intrinsic and extrinsic simultaneously?

mlos.text: Explain the components of language and theories of language acquisition
Analyze different theories of intelligence and evaluate their evidence
Apply motivation theories to personal, academic, and workplace scenarios
Distinguish between different theories of emotion and their implications
Interpret data on intelligence, emotional intelligence, and motivation

activities.title: LA1: Key Concepts - Cognition & Motivation
activities.studentInstructions: Match key terms and concepts related to cognition, language, intelligence, emotion, and motivation.

activities.title: LA2: Intelligence Controversies
activities.studentInstructions: Analyze controversies in intelligence research (nature/nurture, multiple intelligences, IQ testing bias, cultural factors). Evaluate evidence for different perspectives.

activities.title: LA3: Data Literacy - The Flynn Effect
activities.studentInstructions: Interpret graphs showing IQ score increases over time (Flynn Effect). Answer questions about possible explanations (education, nutrition, test-taking skills, environmental complexity).

activities.title: LA4: Motivation Application
activities.studentInstructions: Analyze your own motivation for college using 3 motivation theories (drive-reduction, arousal, self-determination). Identify intrinsic vs extrinsic factors.

modules.title: Personality & Social Psychology
inquiryQuestions: To what extent is your personality shaped by genetics vs experience?
Why do good people do bad things in certain social situations?
How do we maintain positive self-concepts despite contradictory evidence?

mlos.text: Compare major personality theories and their implications
Analyze the research evidence for trait stability vs change
Apply social psychology principles to explain conformity, obedience, and persuasion
Evaluate the role of cognitive dissonance in attitude change
Distinguish prejudice, stereotyping, and discrimination using psychological research

activities.title: LA1: Personality & Social Psych Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match personality theories, social psychology concepts, and classic study findings to their descriptions.

activities.title: LA2: Classic Studies Analysis
activities.studentInstructions: Deep dive into Milgram obedience study, Asch conformity experiments, and Stanford Prison Experiment. What do they tell us about human nature? What are the ethical concerns?

activities.title: LA3: Data Literacy - Personality Stability
activities.studentInstructions: Interpret longitudinal research data on personality change across lifespan. Analyze Big Five trait stability and change patterns.

activities.title: LA4: Cognitive Dissonance in Action
activities.studentInstructions: Identify cognitive dissonance in 5 real-world scenarios (politics, consumer behavior, relationships). Explain reduction strategies used in each.

modules.title: Psychological Disorders & Health Psychology
inquiryQuestions: Where is the line between normal and abnormal behavior?
How do biological, psychological, and social factors combine to create psychological disorders?
What makes a treatment 'evidence-based'?

mlos.text: Analyze the criteria used to define psychological disorders
Apply the biopsychosocial model to understand major disorder categories
Evaluate the strengths and limitations of DSM-5 diagnostic system
Distinguish evidence-based treatments from pseudoscience
Explain the stress-health connection using physiological and psychological concepts
Apply coping strategies to manage stress effectively

activities.title: LA1: Disorders & Health Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Categorize symptoms by disorder type. Match disorders to DSM-5 criteria and treatment approaches.

activities.title: LA2: Case Study Diagnosis
activities.studentInstructions: Given 3 detailed case studies, identify likely diagnoses using DSM criteria. Explain using biopsychosocial model (biological, psychological, social factors).

activities.title: LA3: Data Literacy - Mental Health Statistics
activities.studentInstructions: Interpret data on disorder prevalence, comorbidity, treatment-seeking rates, and demographic differences. Analyze treatment effectiveness research.

activities.title: LA4: Treatment Evaluation
activities.studentInstructions: Compare evidence for different treatments (CBT, medication, alternative therapies) for one disorder. Identify pseudoscience red flags in questionable treatments.

assessments.title: Portfolio Piece #7: Mental Health Case Study

modules.title: Final Exam & Course Integration
inquiryQuestions: How has your understanding of human behavior and mental processes evolved?
How do psychological concepts connect and reinforce each other across topics?
How will you apply psychological thinking in your life and career?

mlos.text: Synthesize knowledge across all modules to analyze complex scenarios
Apply psychological thinking skills to novel situations
Reflect on personal growth and learning throughout the course

activities.title: LA1: Cumulative Review Activity
activities.studentInstructions: Comprehensive matching, categorization, and concept review covering all 8 modules. Prepares for final exam.

activities.title: LA2: Integration Case Study
activities.studentInstructions: Analyze complex case requiring concepts from multiple modules (e.g., person with memory problems after accident, experiencing stress, developing depression). Explain using biopsychology, learning, cognition, and health psychology.
